Organizational analysis and mapping of protein kinase C -- responsive elements regulating expression in platelets .
Platelet <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are acutely and reversibly upregulated after acute myocardial infarction .

text: The exon-intron structure of the 5 ' portion of the <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene was determined initially by comparing the nucleotide sequence of the 5 ' flanking genomic clone with that of a novel human uterine <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cDNA that extended the mRNA 141 bp further upstream than the previously identified human placental cDNA .

A major transcription initiation site was located in three human tissues approximately 560 bp upstream from the translation initiation codon and 380 bp upstream from any previously identified transcription initiation site .

text: Functional analysis of 5 ' deletion constructs in transfected K562 cells and gel mobility shift localized the major phorbol ester - responsive motifs in the <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter to a cluster of activator protein - 2 ( AP-2 ) binding consensus sites located approximately 1.8 kb 5 ' from the transcription initiation site .

These studies are the first to determine the structure and organization of the 5 ' end of the <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene and demonstrate that <extra_id_0> thromboxane receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression can be regulated by activation of protein kinase C via induction of an AP-2-like nuclear factor binding to upstream promoter elements .
